webTitle: AA prepares to give a breakdown of its results

fields.bodyText: If you sign up to the AA, the roadside recovery firm pledges to cover you and your motor for the next 12 months. But please note: the offer is only available to the firm's customers, not its chief executives. That became clear last month, when the self-proclaimed fourth emergency service eased out boss Chris Jansen just eight months after he'd joined the group – and only two months after the company floated on the stock market. He'd been hired by the AA's old private equity owners, who were preparing to sell the business. But in June the firm announced that Bob Mackenzie, a former boss of rival Green Flag, had gained the support of City investors to bring in his own team to run the business after listing. Cue a pile-up of platitudes about how Mackenzie and Jansen would share the driving – only for the latter to get left on the hard shoulder, where he's been reduced to attempting to thumb a lift from another company. "I have agreed with Bob to find a new executive opportunity outside the AA," Jansen admitted, rather humiliatingly. All of which should get another run-out this week as the company unveils the first set of results since its flotation. So far investors have enjoyed the ride, with shares up about 18%, but Mackenzie now has nobody else to blame if the shares stop purring. Soaps and spray-ons keep investors happy In the 1870s, a pair of Georges – a Brit called Paterson and a Greek called Zochonis – were working together in a Sierra Leone trading company. They became pals and in 1879 set up a trading post of their own, Paterson Zochonis & Company, which dealt with west African exports to Europe while also importing textiles and food to Sierra Leone. After many iterations, their company became what is the present-day PZ Cussons. And while even folk in the City pay little attention to what it's up to (despite its shares being listed on the London Stock Exchange for 61 years), you'll know its products. It plays an intimate role in the country's morning ablutions as the owner of Imperial Leather and Carex soaps and, as the company behind the St Tropez spray-on tan, no doubt supplies today's gorgeous Georges. But lesser known – although it will be mentioned in its trading statement this week – is how the company also tips its hat to its west African roots, with Nigeria accounting for a third of profits. As well as selling soap there, it now has Nigerian joint ventures in electricals and nutrition. Isn't that business scrubbing up nicely? No distraction from Braveheart's woes With impeccable timing, this week sees the annual general meeting of Braveheart Investment Group, an Aim-listed investor in early-stage businesses. Along with its name, its Perth base near Scone Abbey makes the company sound like just the type of entity you'd have expected to have been agitating for Scottish independence – but it turns out that its moniker is as misleading as the Mel Gibson film. In fact, Braveheart is about as British as these firms can be, having offices (and investments) in England and Northern Ireland as well as Scotland. Its boss, Geoffrey Thomson, hardly backed the yes campaign, telling the aptly named Alliance News in July that a yes vote would trigger "capital flight immediately, falling property prices, an exodus to England and considerably higher taxes", because "if oil revenues are not as high as the Scottish National party says they will be, the only way to make up for that is by decreasing public expenditure or by raising taxes. And I think raising taxes is the easier option". Still, the no vote does cause the company a minor irritation: investors attending the group's gathering this week might now want to talk about the firm's profits, which were down 92% last year.

webTitle: Internet giant Alibaba valued at $231bn after frenzied debut as public company

fields.standfirst:
Shares in the Chinese internet giant reach a high of $100 as founder Jack Ma says ‘We want to be bigger than Walmart’

  • Follow all the latest on the Alibaba IPO
fields.body:
Alibaba, the Chinese internet giant, made a frenzied debut on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday ending its first day as a public company valued at over $231bn, more than Facebook or Amazon and eBay combined.

The biggest ever share sale in the US got off to a flying – if delayed – start on Friday as investors snapped up stock. Shares initially priced at $68 reached a high of $100 at one point before settling back to $93.89 by the end of the day, up 38%.

Founded by Jack Ma, a former English teacher who started the site from his one-bedroom apartment in Hangzhou in 1998, Alibaba now controls 80% of online commerce in China.

Ma cemented his position as China’s richest man with the sale. The value of his Alibaba shares is now close to $19bn.

“We have a dream,” Ma said as he rang the opening bell to officially launch the flotation on the NYSE. “We hope in the next 15 years the world changes because of us. We hope in 15 years people say this is a company like Microsoft, IBM, Walmart. They changed, shaped the world … We want to be bigger than Walmart.”


Alibaba will have to add another $20bn to make that dream come true, but the company is already more valuable than many of its US tech peers and JP Morgan Chase.

Ma raised $21.8bn from the sale and now has a huge war chest with which to expand the business. He has ambitions to grow the business in the US as well as Europe and China.

Rapid Ratings chief executive James Gellert said the initial public offering (IPO) marked a watershed moment. “This puts the US on notice that global tech is about more than Silicon Valley,” he said. “Every tech company in the US that is in Alibaba’s general business is paying close attention. This company is going to be a formidable competitor with a tremendous amount of cash.”

Alibaba’s share sale was expected to start at 10.30am, but was delayed as officials worked their way through a huge number of orders from retail investors. Over 1,700 investment firms worldwide are believed to have put in orders for shares.

Sam Hamadeh, chief executive of analyst PrivCo, said the delay was unusual. “But this is an unusual IPO because it so large,” he said.

He pointed to Facebook’s IPO in 2012, which proved a disaster, as the Nasdaq’s systems were overwhelmed by orders for what was then the largest tech IPO of all time. “They clearly want to get this right,” he said.

In an interview with CNBC, Ma said he believed that his customers and employees should come before shareholders, but added: “I am very honoured and so excited … the responsibility I’ve been thinking about the next five to 10 years is: how can I make sure these shareholders are happy?”

Ma told CNBC that he had got the idea for his business when he visited the US, and looks to Forrest Gump for inspiration. Ma said he had watched the Tom Hanks movie at least 10 times.

“Every time I’m frustrated, I watch the movie,” he said. “I watched the movie again before I came here. It’s telling me: ‘No matter what changes, you are you.’”
